Award.AwardTitle: International Travel Support for The Scientific Committee on Solar-Terrestrial Physics 13th Quadrennial Solar-Terrestrial Physics Symposium; October 12-17, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Scientific Committee on Solar-Terrestrial Physics (SCOSTEP) 13th Quadrennial Solar-Terrestrial Physics Symposium (STP 13), to be held October 12 through 17, 2014, in XiAn, Shanxi, China is an important international meeting that will attract key scientists and students from around the world working in solar-terrestrial studies. SCOSTEP has sponsored many multi-year solar-terrestrial programs, the most recent being the Climate and Weather of the Sun Earth System (CAWSES) I and II programs extending from 2005 thru 2013. The new SCOSTEP program is the Variability of the Sun and Its Terrestrial Impact (VarSITI) program, extending over the next 5 years. The STP13 Symposium will highlight the scientific results obtained during the previous CAWSES II program and the first new results from VarSITI. VarSITI has four scientific elements that address key solar terrestrial problems of current interest including the current low solar activity. These involve solar evolution and extreme events, Earth affecting solar transients, the coupled inner-magnetospheric environment, and the middle atmosphere/thermosphere/ionosphere role in climate.
This award supports the travel and meeting expenses for up to seven distinguished U.S. scientists to attend the meeting. A major focus of the discussions will be data analysis, modeling, and theory to improve to improve understanding of how solar variability affects Earth. The U.S. scientists that will be sponsored are essential for organizing key aspects of the meeting and the results that will be discussed there. Students from many countries will attend the meeting and benefit from the participation of the sponsored U.S. scientists. These scientists will also be available to participate in media and public outreach activities. The presentations will be published in the STP 13 symposium proceedings, and many journal publications will result from the interactions of the attendees. The sponsored U.S. scientists will help promote such publications and may be coauthors of papers and even editors of the proceedings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to provide International Travel Support for the travel and meeting expenses for six distinguished U.S. scientists to attend the Scientific Committee on Solar-Terrestrial Physics (SCOSTEP) 13th Quadrennial Solar-Terrestrial Physics Symposium (STP-13) that was held October 12 - 18, 2014 in XiAn, Shanxi, China. The main goal of the meeting was to highlight the scientific results obtained during previous and current SCOSTEP-sponsored programs, including the first new results from the Variability of the Sun and Its Terrestrial Impact (VarSITI) program. Five scientific elements addressing key solar-terrestrial problems that were discussed were solar evolution and extreme events, Earth-affecting solar transients, the coupled inner-magnetospheric environment, the middle atmosphere/ thermosphere/ ionosphere role in climate, and star-planet interactions. Nearly 200 presentations, consisting of invited and contributed talks and posters, were made at the meeting. Many of the 260 attendees were students or young scientists from China an dother Asian countries. Outreach activities for the media and public were performed by the local organizers. The meeting location Xi’an, was once the capital city of ancient China, and long the political, economic, and cultural center of China and East Asia. The attendees were able to participate in cultural tours of the area. 

A special section, named after VarSITI, of the Journal of Geophysics Research - Space Physics is being published online: http://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/agu/issue/10.1002/(ISSN)2169-9402(CAT)SpecialIssues(VI)VarSITI1/. 

The editors are Qiang Hu, Bernd Funke, Martin Kaufmann, Olga Khabarova, Jean-Pierre Raulin, Craig J. Rodger, and David F. Webb. It includes articles of authors who presented talks at STP13, in addition to those from the broader space physics community. This collection covers topics including solar dynamo theory, short and long-term variability of solar activity and their impact, and the corresponding responses in geospace and in the atmosphere. 

Overall this meeting, and the SCOSTEP and VarSITI programs themselves, strive for international collaboration in data analysis, modeling, and theory to understand how solar variability affects Earth and its society. Goals include developing and sustaining student interest in Sun-Earth Connections, promoting efficient exchange of data and information between scientists in all countries, and seeking projects and programs that cross over traditional boundaries of physical regions and focused scientific disciplines. This research benefits society by studying the causes and effects of space weather on both civilian and military activities.
